{{Use Australian English|date=June 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox legislation |short_title = Age Discrimination Act 2004 |legislature = [[Parliament of Australia]] |image = Coat of Arms of Australia.svg |imagesize = |imagealt = Australian Coat of Arms |caption = |long_title = <!--There is no long title--> |citation = {{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|act|ada2004174|Age Discrimination Act 2004}} |enacted_by = [[Australian House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] |date_enacted = |date_passed = |enacted_by2 = [[Australian Senate|Senate]] |date_enacted2 = |date_passed2 = |royal_assent = 22 Jun 2004 |date_commenced = 23 Jun 2004 |bill = Age Discrimination Bill 2003 |bill_citation = |bill_date = |introduced_by = [[Daryl Williams (politician)|Daryl Williams]]<ref name="roadmap">[https://www.humanrights.gov.au/roadmap-ada-age-discrimination-act-2004-2007 "Roadmap to ADA: The Age Discrimination Act 2004"], Joanna Hemingway, 2007.</ref> |1st_reading = 26 Jun 2003 |2nd_reading = 26 Nov 2003 |3rd_reading = 26 Nov 2003 |committee_report = |bill2 = Age Discrimination Bill 2003 |bill_citation2 = |bill_date2 = |introduced_by2 = |1st_reading2 = 1 Dec 2003 |2nd_reading2 = 3 Dec 2003 |3rd_reading2 = 29 Mar 2004 |committee_report2 = |white_paper = |amendments = {{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|act|adaa2006254|Age Discrimination Amendment Act 2006}} |repeals = |related_legislation = {{Cite Legislation AU|Cth|act|adpa2004462|Age Discrimination (Consequential Provisions) Act 2004}} |summary = |keywords = |status = in force }}
The '''Age Discrimination Act 2004''' is an [[Act of Parliament|Act]] of the [[Parliament of Australia]] that prohibits [[age discrimination]] in many areas including [[employment]], [[education]], [[lodging|accommodation]] and the provision of goods and services. Persons of any age can be discriminated against within the meaning of the act.
Some exemptions are provided, including for [[religious organisation]]s, [[charitable organisation]]s and [[positive discrimination]].
Complaints of discrimination must first be made to the [[Australian Human Rights Commission]] (AHRC), where a [[conciliation]] process can be initiated. Filing a complaint is free.<ref name="ahrc1">[https://www.humanrights.gov.au/complaints-under-age-discrimination-act "Complaints under the Age Discrimination Act"], [[Australian Human Rights Commission]].</ref> If the complaint is not resolved through the conciliation process, it can be taken to the [[Federal Court of Australia|Federal Court]] or the [[Federal Circuit Court of Australia|Federal Circuit Court]].
In general, age discrimination is not a criminal offence. However, the Act creates criminal offences of discriminatory advertising, victimisation and failure to disclose statistical or actuarial data upon request by the President of the AHRC. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.humanrights.gov.au/sites/default/files/content/legal/FDL/2011/2_Age.pdf|title=Federal Discrimination Law|at=Section 2.1.4|date=21 October 2011|publisher=[[Australian Human Rights Commission]]|access-date = 11 December 2015}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Keech v Metropolitan Health Service]] * [[List of anti-discrimination acts]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:2004 in Australian law]] [[Category:Acts of the Parliament of Australia]] [[Category:Ageism]] [[Category:Anti-discrimination law in Australia]] [[Category:Children's rights legislation]]

revision.comment: Fixing cite error ([[:Category:Pages with citations using unsupported parameters|you can help!]]); work= is correct for BBC News. The publisher would be the BBC
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox person | name = Ahmed Wali Karzai
{{lang|ps|احمد ولي کرزی}} | image = Ahmad Wali Karzai in 2010 (cropped).jpg | alt = | caption = Ahmed Wali Karzai speaking to the media following a [[shura]] in [[Kandahar]] in June 2010. | birth_name = | birth_date = 1961 | birth_place = [[Karz, Kandahar|Karz]], [[Kandahar Province]], [[Afghanistan]] | death_date = {{Death date|2011|7|12|df=yes}} (aged 50) | death_place = [[Kandahar]], Afghanistan | other_names = | known_for = Politics, running a restaurant | occupation = Politician, businessman | children = 2 sons and 3 daughters |nationality ={{AFG}} }} '''Ahmed Wali Karzai''' ({{lang-ps|احمد ولي کرزی}}, {{transl|ps|''Aḥmad Walī Karzay''}}, 1961 – 12 July 2011) was a [[Politics of Afghanistan|politician]] in [[Afghanistan]] who served as Chairman of the [[Kandahar Provincial Council]] from 2005 until his death.{{cite web|url=http://www.afghan-web.com/bios/wali_karzai.html|title=Ahmad Wali Karzai|publisher=Afghanistan Online|author=Abdullah Qazi|date=16 October 2008}}{{cite news |url=http://www.results.jemb.org/results.asp?ElectionID=2&ProvinceID=28&Order=Vote |title=Wolesi Jirga & Provincial Council Elections Afghanistan 2005 Elections |author= |accessdate=10 June 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.results.jemb.org%2Fresults.asp%3FElectionID%3D2%26ProvinceID%3D28%26Order%3DVote&date=2008-06-13 |archivedate=13 June 2008 |df=dmy-all }} He was the younger paternal half-brother of former [[List of Presidents of Afghanistan|Afghan President]] [[Hamid Karzai]] and an elder of the [[Popalzai]] tribe. Wali Karzai formerly lived in the United States where he managed a restaurant owned by his family. He returned to Afghanistan following the removal of the [[Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan|Taliban government]] in late 2001. He has been accused of political corruption[[Tariq Ali]], New Left Review 50, March–April 2008. "[http://www.newleftreview.org/?page=article&view=2713|Afghanistan: Mirage of the Good War]" and was allegedly on the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] payroll.Filkins, Dexter, Mark Mazzetti, and James Risen (27 October 2009)."[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/28/world/asia/28intel.html Brother of Afghan leader said to be paid by C.I.A.]". ''[[The New York Times]]''. He was assassinated by one of his close bodyguards, Sardar Mohammad, on 12 July 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43721864/ns/world_news-south_and_central_asia/ |title='Good friend' kills Afghan president's half-brother |publisher=msnbc.com |date=12 July 2011 |accessdate=2011-07-12| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110713002524/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43721864/ns/world_news-south_and_central_asia/| archivedate= 13 July 2011 | deadurl= no}} ==Early life and political career== Karzai was born in 1961 in the village of [[Karz, Kandahar|Karz]] in [[Kandahar Province]], Afghanistan.{{cite news|title=Profile: Ahmad Wali Karzai |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/8332532.stm|author=Alastair Lawson|work=BBC News|date=26 May 2010|accessdate=9 April 2011}} He is the son of [[Abdul Ahad Karzai]] and brother of [[Hamid Karzai]], [[Mahmud Karzai]] and [[Qayum Karzai]]. He attended [[Habibia High School]] in [[Kabul]] but was not able to finish his studies due to the [[Soviet–Afghan War]]. He travelled to neighbouring [[Pakistan]] and then immigrated to the United States.[http://www.pajhwok.com/en/2011/07/13/wali-karzai-laid-rest Wali Karzai laid to rest]. Pajhwok.com. Retrieved on 2011-07-14. Wali Karzai managed an [[Afghan cuisine|Afghan restaurant]] in [[Chicago]] that was owned by his family.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/29/world/29cables.html?pagewanted=4&_r=1&hp |work=The New York Times |title=Cables Obtained by WikiLeaks Shine Light Into Secret Diplomatic Channels |first1=Scott |last1=Shane |first2=Andrew W. |last2=Lehren |date=28 November 2010}} Ahmad Wali returned to Pakistan in the late 1980s to help his father, Abdul Ahad. He came to political prominence in Afghanistan following the US occupation of the country in 2001, where he was a key ally of the US military in the country's south.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/mobile/world-south-asia-14114771|title=Obituary: Ahmad Wali Karzai|last=Lawson|first=Alastair|date=12 July 2011|work=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=12 July 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719141357/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/mobile/world-south-asia-14114771|archivedate=19 July 2011 |deadurl=no}} He was elected to the [[Kandahar Provincial Council]] in 2005 and exercised influence in the province to the extent that he was described as "effectively the governor".{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/07/201171283244784171.html|title=Obituary: Ahmed Wali Karzai |date=12 July 2011|publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]|accessdate=12 July 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110712123322/http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/07/201171283244784171.html|archivedate=12 July 2011 |deadurl=no}} At the time of his death, he was the Council's chairman.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/afghanistan/8632131/Ahmad-Wali-Karzai-assassination-huge-propaganda-boost-for-Taliban.html|title=Ahmad Wali Karzai assassination 'huge propaganda boost for Taliban'|last=Ramakrishnan|first=Arvind|date=12 July 2011|work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|accessdate=12 July 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110712201614/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/afghanistan/8632131/Ahmad-Wali-Karzai-assassination-huge-propaganda-boost-for-Taliban.html|archivedate=12 July 2011 |deadurl=no}} A few days before his death, Ahmed Wali Karzai appeared on a British television programme, "Afghanistan: The Unknown Country," presented by [[Lyse Doucet]], at his home in Kandahar, talking about public perceptions of him.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-14129187 BBC News: "Ahmad Wali Karzai: Meeting Kandahar's Mr Fix-it", 12 July 2011]. BBC News (2011-05-29). Retrieved on 2011-07-14. Doucet said: "Like most strong men, he depended on family and fellow tribesmen to protect him." ==Allegations of corruption== A June 2009 [[U.S. Embassy, Kabul|U.S. embassy]] cable alleged that much of the actual business of running the Afghan city of Kandahar "takes place out of public sight, where Ahmed Wali Karzai operates, parallel to formal government structures, through a network of political clans that use state institutions to protect and enable licit and illicit enterprises." [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/dec/02/us-karzai-half-brother-wikileaks US convinced Karzai half-brother is corrupt, WikiLeaks cables say] by Jonathan Steele, [[The Guardian (UK)|''The Guardian'']], 2 December 2010 In addition, [[James Risen]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' and others stated that Ahmed Wali Karzai may have been involved in the [[opium production in Afghanistan|Afghan opium and heroin trade]]. This was denied by Karzai, who called the charges political [[propaganda]] and stated he was a "victim of vicious politics."{{cite news|first=James|last=Risen|authorlink=James Risen|title=Reports Link Karzai's Brother to Afghan Heroin Trade |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/05/world/asia/05afghan.html?ref=asia|work=The New York Times|location=United States |id= |date=4 October 2008|accessdate=5 October 2008}} In meetings with Afghan President Hamid Karzai, including a 2006 session with former [[United States Ambassador to Afghanistan|US Ambassador to Afghanistan]], [[Ronald E. Neumann]], the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]]'s station chief and their British counterparts, American officials talked about the rumors in hopes that the president might move his brother out of the country, said several people who took part in or were briefed on the talks. "We thought the concern expressed to Karzai might be enough to get him out of there," one official said. President Karzai has resisted, however, demanding clear-cut evidence of wrongdoing, several officials said. "We don't have the kind of hard, direct evidence that you could take to get a criminal indictment," a [[White House]] official said. Ahmed Wali Karzai dismissed the allegations as politically motivated attacks by longtime rival groups in his country. Before the [[Afghan presidential election, 2009|2009 Afghan presidential election]], Wali Karzai and [[Sher Mohammad Akhundzada]], former governor of the [[Helmand Province]] and a member of the [[Meshrano Jirga|Upper House]] of the Afghan parliament, were accused of vote rigging.{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article6792729.ece |title=President Karzai’s supporters ‘buy’ votes for Afghanistan election |date=12 August 2009 |work=The Times |location=UK |author=Tom Coghlan |accessdate=9 April 2011}} After the election, reports mentioned that all those running in the election were involved in [[electoral fraud]]. ==CIA connections== In October 2009 ''The New York Times'' reported that Ahmed Wali Karzai received payments from the [[CIA]] for "a variety of services", including the recruitment of the [[Kandahar Strike Force]], an [[ANA Commando Brigade|Afghan paramilitary force]] run by the CIA in the Kandahar region. It also stated that he was paid for allowing the CIA and [[United States special operations forces|U.S. special forces]] to rent the former residence of Taliban supreme leader [[Mohammed Omar|Mullah Omar]]. However, Karzai has denied taking any payment from the CIA.Posner, Gerald (28 October 2009). "[http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2009-10-28/the-karzai-brothers-fight-back/full/ The Karzai brothers fight back]". ''[[The Daily Beast]]''. [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[John Kerry]] and former [[Afghanistan – United States relations|Afghan Ambassador to the United States]], [[Said Tayeb Jawad]], defended Karzai in recent years, Kerry saying "We should not condemn Ahmed Wali Karzai or damage our critical relations with his brother, President Karzai, on the basis of newspaper articles or rumors"[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hCHv88Vg95pGUC2KXpUHvJ1S9MkQ Kerry calls for briefing on Karzai brother], AFP, 28 October 2009statement made 28 October 2009 and Jawad saying, "There is presence of the intelligence, there's presence of many institutions of the United States and [[NATO]] countries in Afghanistan, why don't they come up with a clear evidence of any corruption involving the president or his family?"[http://www.pajhwok.com/en/2010/07/05/karzai-has-less-50000-his-bank-account-jawad Karzai has less than $50,000 in his bank account: Jawad] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328035333/http://www.pajhwok.com/en/2010/07/05/karzai-has-less-50000-his-bank-account-jawad |date=28 March 2012 }}, Pajhwok, 5 July 2010[[Said Tayeb Jawad]] on 5 July 2010 ==Assassination== {{wikinews|Ahmad Wali Karzai, brother of Afghan President, shot dead in Kandahar}} Karzai survived a number of assassination attempts by [[Taliban insurgency|Taliban militants]]"[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/8055247.stm Karzai brother 'survives attack']". ''[[BBC News]]''. 18 May 2009. and at least two attacks against his office in Kandahar: one in November 2008'[http://www.canada.com/ottawacitizen/story.html?id=1c71b1ff-225d-463b-8589-daf50ca6727e "Suicide bomber attacks Afghan government office"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121106095616/http://www.canada.com/ottawacitizen/story.html?id=1c71b1ff-225d-463b-8589-daf50ca6727e |date=6 November 2012 }}. 12 November 2008 and the other in April 2009.Coghlan, Tom (2 April 2009). "[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article6017334.ece Brother of Afghan President Hamid Karzai escapes as suicide attackers kill 17]". ''The Times''. According to Karzai himself, he had survived a total of nine assassination attempts.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/podcasts/series/docarchive Assignment: The Afghan Governors]. ''[[BBC]]'' 28 July 2011 On 12 July 2011, Karzai was assassinated by his long-time head of security, Sardar Mohammad. Reports say that Wali was shot twice with a pistol, once in the head and once in the chest, as he was coming out of the bathroom inside his residence.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-14118884 |title=Afghan president's brother, Ahmad Wali Karzai, killed |work=BBC News |date=June 12, 2011 |accessdate=2011-07-12| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110712112112/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-14118884| archivedate= 12 July 2011 | deadurl= no}} Abdul Raziq, Police Chief of Kandahar, stated that the assailant Sardar Mohammad was well known by the [[Karzai]] family. He had served as Wali Karzai's most trusted security guard for the last seven years. "As he entered Wali's room, Wali came out of his bathroom. Mohammad fired twice at Wali without any conversation passing between the two. Wali received one bullet in the chest and second in the head," Abdul Raziq said.[http://www.pajhwok.com/en/2011/07/12/suspects-arrested-wali-assassination Suspects arrested in Wali assassination]. Pajhwok.com. Retrieved on 2011-07-14. The assailant was immediately killed by other bodyguards and then his body was hanged at a city square on public view.[http://publicintelligence.net/ahmed-wali-karzais-assassin-sardar-mohammad-corpse-photos/ Sardar Mohammad Corpse Photos]. publicintelligence.com. Retrieved on 2012-06-04.[http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Backchannels/2011/0712/Ahmad-Wali-Karzai-was-an-indispensable-problem Ahmad Wali Karzai was an indispensable problem]. Csmonitor.com. Retrieved on 2011-07-14. In the meantime, Karzai's body was taken to [[Mirwais Hospital]] in Kandahar.[http://www.pajhwok.com/en/2011/07/12/president-karzai%E2%80%99s-brother-wali-killed-updated President Karzai’s brother Wali killed – Updated]. Pajhwok.com. Retrieved on 2011-07-14. Thousands of people turned up for his funeral the next day, led by Afghan President Hamid Karzai, and many more waited in buses where his body lay to be taken to his hometown of [[Karz, Kandahar|Karz]]. Security was tightened around the funeral procession and some reports indicated Hamid Karzai's elite security team were deployed to secure [[Kandahar]], where the funeral was held.{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia/2011/07/20117127299662659.html |title=Karzai’s brother shot dead in Kandahar |publisher=aljazeera.net |date=12 June 2011 |accessdate=2011-07-13| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110712123320/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia/2011/07/20117127299662659.html| archivedate= 12 July 2011 | deadurl= no}} At the funeral procession Hamid Karzai issued a message to the Taliban:{{quote|"My message for [the Taliban] is that my countryman, my brother, stop killing your own people. It's easy to kill and everyone can do it, but the real man is the one who can save people's lives."{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-14133518 |title=Afghan president's brother, Ahmad Wali Karzai, buried |work=BBC News |date=13 July 2011 |accessdate=2011-07-16| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110715022356/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-14133518| archivedate= 15 July 2011 | deadurl= no}}|[[Hamid Karzai]], [[President of Afghanistan]]}} Hamid Karzai's spokesman Waheed Omer said that "We know we live in a dangerous country. We know that security has to be tight all the time and the president knows [this]. He's got good security and that is not a worry for the president. The president is upset, he is still in grief, about the death of his brother. Wali was a very close brother of the president."[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia/2011/07/20117134384513388.html Violence surrounds Wali Karzai's funeral – Central & South Asia]. Al Jazeera English. Retrieved on 2011-07-14. En route to the funeral [[List of governors of Helmand|Helmand Governor]] [[Gulab Mangal]] escaped an assassination attempt, while later in the evening two more blasts went off in Kandahar. Though Hamid Karzai led the funeral procession, he was not present at a memorial service which was attacked by a suicide bomber killing the senior cleric of the mosque Hikmatullah Hikmat, the head of the Provincial Ulema Council, who died along with three others while 13 others were also wounded.{{cite news |title=Cleric killed in Kandahar mosque blast |publisher=[[Al Jazeera]] |date=14 July 2011 |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia/2011/07/20117147513217465.html}} ===Reactions=== President Hamid Karzai issued a statement on the day his brother died saying: "My younger brother was martyred in his house today. This is the life of all Afghan people, I hope these miseries which every Afghan family faces will one day end" Afghan families, every one of us, have suffered from it, and we hope, God willing, for our suffering to be over. US General David Petraeus {{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-14118884 |title='Afghan president's brother, Ahmad Wali Karzai, killed |work=BBC News |date=12 July 2011 |accessdate=2011-07-13 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110712201742/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-14118884 |archivedate=12 July 2011 |deadurl=no}} as well as other top NATO personnel serving in Afghanistan, officials at the [[White House]] and many world leaders condemned the assassination. [[Taliban]] spokesman [[Mohammad Yousef Ahmadi|Qari Yousef Ahmadi]] claimed that one of their agents was behind the assassination saying, "Today in Kandahar city, Hamid Karzai's brother was killed during the Operation al-Badr... We hired a person by the name of Sadar Mohammad, who was hired for this job for some time now. Ahmed Wali Karzai was punished for all his wrongdoings." However, according to ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]'', the Taliban has "a dubious record of claiming responsibility for attacks it had nothing to do with",[http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Asia-South-Central/2011/0712/What-Ahmed-Wali-Karzai-s-assassination-could-mean-for-Afghanistan What Ahmed Wali Karzai's assassination could mean for Afghanistan], by Tom A. Peter, ''Christian Science Monitor'', 12 July 2011 and its claim has been denied by several sources. Abdul Ghafar Sayedzada, head of the counter-terrorism department at the [[Ministry of the Interior (Afghanistan)|Interior Ministry]], told [[Reuters]] that "It appears Ahmed Wali Karzai has been killed by one of his bodyguard, and there was nobody from outside involved." The news was confirmed by Zalmai Ayubi, the spokesman for Kandahar province, as well as by Sediq Sediqqi, a spokesman for the Ministry of Interior. Following the killing, police were mobilised in Kandahar and helicopters were seen overhead as checkpoints were locked down leading towards the hospital his body was taken to.{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia/2011/07/20117127299662659.html |title=Karzai's brother shot dead in Kandahar |date=12 July 2011 |publisher=Al Jazeera}} ===Investigations=== Investigators believe that Sardar Mohammad may have been a Taliban [[sleeper agent]] or a government defector. [[Mahmud Karzai]], Karzai's other brother, stated that Sardar Mohammad traveled to the Pakistani city of [[Quetta]] within the past three months to meet with the [[Quetta Shura|Shura Council]] of the Taliban. Mahmoud Karzai claimed that he has been acting very erratically in recent weeks, including [[insomnia|sleeping poorly]], moving from house to house during nights, acting suspiciously toward his men and demanding to know who they were talking to on their [[mobile phone]]s. It suggests that he may have been using [[narcotic]]s since the area is well known for [[Opium production in Afghanistan|opium production]].http://in.news.yahoo.com/karzais-killer-traveled-pak-meet-taliban-insurgents-weeks-120015970.html ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Ahmad Wali Karzai}} *[http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1932993,00.html?xid=rss-world Ahmed Wali Karzai]. ''Time Magazine'' *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091003124139/http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2009-09-27/heroin-kingpin-or-hero Karzai Family Secrets] *[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/10/28/ahmed-wali-karzai-denies-_n_337070.html Ahmed Wali Karzai Denies CIA Pay] *[http://www.csmonitor.com/2009/1029/p02s01-usmi.html Ahmed Wali Karzai and the CIA: America's conundrum in Afghanistan] *[http://www.understandingwar.org/report/politics-and-power-kandahar Politics and Power in Kandahar] {{DEFAULTSORT:Karzai, Ahmed Wali}} [[Category:Afghan businesspeople]] [[Category:Afghan politicians]] [[Category:Assassinated Afghan politicians]] [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:Afghan expatriates in the United States]] [[Category:Afghan Sunni Muslims]] [[Category:Pashtun people]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Afghanistan]] [[Category:Murder in 2011]] [[Category:People murdered in Afghanistan]] [[Category:Karzai family|Ahmed]] [[Category:Hamid Karzai]] [[Category:Corruption in Afghanistan]] [[Category:21st-century Afghan politicians]]

revision.comment: turned out not to be his tomb + no source for name of spouse
revision.text:
{{redirect|Ahuizotl|the mythical animal|Ahuizotl (mythology)}} {{Infobox monarch | name = Ahuizotl | title = [[List of Tenochtitlan rulers|8th]] [[Hueyi Tlatoani|Tlatoani of Tenochtitlan]]
Ruler of the [[Aztec Triple Alliance]] | image = Ahuitzotl.jpg | caption = Ahuitzotl in the ''[[Codex Mendoza]]'' | reign = [[Aztec calendar|7 Rabbit]] (1486) – [[Aztec calendar|10 Rabbit]] (1502) | predecessor = [[Tizoc]] | successor = [[Moctezuma II]] | queen = | issue = King [[Chimalpilli II]]
King [[Cuauhtémoc]]
Daughter | father = [[Tezozomoc (son of Itzcoatl)|Tezozomoc]] | mother = [[Atotoztli II]] | birth_date = | death_date = [[Aztec calendar|10 Rabbit]] (1502) | death_place = }} '''Ahuitzotl''' ({{lang-nah|[[wikt:ahuitzotl|āhuitzotl]]}}, {{IPA-nah|aːˈwit͡sot͡ɬ|-|Awisotl.ogg}}) was the eighth [[Aztec]] ruler, the ''[[Hueyi Tlatoani]]'' of the city of [[Tenochtitlan]], son of princess [[Atotoztli II]]. He was responsible for much of the expansion of the Mexica domain, and consolidated the empire's power after emulating his predecessor. He took power as [[tlatoani]] in the year [[Aztec calendar|7 Rabbit]] (1486), after the death of his predecessor and brother, [[Tizoc]]. His sons were kings [[Chimalpilli II]] and [[Cuauhtémoc]] and he also had one daughter. == Biography == Perhaps the greatest known military leader of [[Pre-Columbian]] [[Mesoamerica]], Ahuizotl began his reign by suppressing a [[Huastec civilization|Huastec]] rebellion, and then swiftly more than doubled the size of lands under Aztec dominance. He conquered the [[Mixtec]], [[Zapotec civilization|Zapotec]], and other peoples from [[Pacific Coast of Mexico]] down to the western part of [[Guatemala]]. Ahuizotl also supervised a major rebuilding of Tenochtitlan on a grander scale including the expansion of the Great Pyramid or [[Great Pyramid of Tenochtitlan|Templo Mayor]] in the year [[Aztec calendar|8 Reed]] (1487). He presided over the introduction of the [[great-tailed grackle]] into the Valley of Mexico, the earliest documented case of human-mediated bird introduction in the Western Hemisphere.{{cite journal|title=Introduction of the Great-tailed Grackle (''Quiscalus mexicanus'') by Aztec Emperor Auitzotl: Provenance of the historical account (La Introducción de la Quiscalus mexicanus por el Emperador Azteca Auitzotl: Origen del Relato Histórico)|first=Paul D.|last=Haemig|work=The Auk|volume=129|number=1|date=January 2012|pages=70–75|publisher=University of California Press|jstor=10.1525/auk.2011.11058|doi=10.1525/auk.2011.11058}} Ahuizotl died in the year [[Aztec calendar|10 Rabbit]] (1502) and was succeeded by his nephew, [[Moctezuma II]]. Ahuizotl took his name from the [[Ahuizotl (creature)|animal ahuizotl]], which the Aztecs considered to be a legendary creature in its own right rather than a mere mythical representation of the king. ==Map== [[File:Aztecexpansion.png|thumb|none|550px| Map showing the expansion of the Aztec empire showing the areas conquered by the Aztec rulers. The conquests of Ahuitzotl is marked by the colour yellow.Based on the maps by Ross Hassig in "Aztec Warfare".]] ==In popular culture== * Under the name Teomitl, Ahuitzotl is a primary character in the ''Obsidian and Blood'' series by [[Aliette de Bodard]], which are set in the last year of the reign of [[Axayacatl]] and the first years of the reign of [[Tizoc]]. ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * Townsend, Richard F. (2000) ''The Aztecs''. revised ed. Thames and Hudson, New York. * Hassig, Ross (1988) ''Aztec Warfare: Imperial Expansion and Political Control''. University of Oklahoma Press, Norman. * {{cite book |last=Weaver |first=Muriel Porter |title=The Aztecs, Maya, and Their Predecessors: Archaeology of Mesoamerica |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I0MATwEACAAJ |edition=3rd |year=1993 |publisher=Academic Press |location=San Diego |isbn=978-0-01-263999-3 }} ==External links== {{Commons category|Ahuitzotl}} * [http://www.ancient.eu/Ahuitzotl/ Ahuitzotl - Ancient History Encyclopedia] {{s-start}} {{s-reg}} {{s-bef |before=[[Tizoc]] }} {{s-ttl |title=[[Tlatoani of Tenochtitlan]] |years=[[Aztec calendar|7 Rabbit – 10 Rabbit]]
(1486–1502) }} {{s-aft |after=[[Moctezuma II]] }} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ahuizotl}} [[Category:Aztec nobility]] [[Category:Tenochca tlatoque]] [[Category:15th-century births]] [[Category:1502 deaths]] [[Category:15th-century rulers]] [[Category:15th-century monarchs in North America]] [[Category:15th-century indigenous people of the Americas]] [[Category:15th century in the Aztec civilization]] [[Category:1500s in the Aztec civilization]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Place of birth unknown]] [[Category:Place of death unknown]]

revision.comment: Rep [[typographic ligature]]s like "ﬁ" with plain text; possible ref cleanup; [[WP:GenFixes]] on, replaced: ﬁ → fi using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
An '''amplified conference''' is a conference or similar event in which the talks and discussions at the conference are 'amplified' through use of networked technologies in order to extend the reach of the conference deliberations. The term was originally coined by [[Lorcan Dempsey]] in a blog post.<ref>{{cite web|author =Dempsey, Lorcan |title=The amplified conference|url=http://orweblog.oclc.org/archives/001404.html|date=July 25, 2007|accessdate=2008-08-30}}</ref> The term is now widely used within the academic and research community with Wankel <ref>{{cite book|author =Wankel, Charles |title=Higher Education Administration with Social Media|isbn=0857246518}}</ref> proposing the following definition:
<cite>''The extension of a physical event (or a series of events) through the use of social media tools for expanding access to (aspects of) the event beyond physical and temporal bounds. Such amplification takes place in the context of intent to make the most of the intellectual content, discussion, networking, and discovery initiated by the event through the process of sharing with co-attendees, colleagues, friends and wider informed publics.''</cite>
A paper by <ref>{{cite web|author1=Haider, Jutta |author2=Huvila, Isto |author3=Cox, Andrew |author4=Francke, Helena |author5=Hall, Hazel |title=Transformation or continuity? The impact of social media on information: implications for theory and practice|url=https://www.asis.org/asist2012/proceedings/Submissions/101.pdf|accessdate=2012-11-20}}</ref> illustrates how amplified conferences are becoming mainstream in a discussion on "''how social media have been employed as part of the project, particularly around event amplification''".
As described by Guy in the Ariadne ejournal <ref>{{cite web|author =Guy, Marieke|title=10 Cheap and Easy Ways to Amplify Your Event|url=http://www.ariadne.ac.uk/issue66/guy/|date=January 30, 2011|accessdate=2012-04-04}}</ref> the term is not a prescriptive one, but rather describes a pattern of behaviors which initially took place at IT and Web-oriented conferences once WiFi networks started to become available at conference venues and delegates started to bring with them networked devices such as laptops and, more recently, PDAs and mobile phones.
==Different Approaches to 'Amplification' of Conferences== There are a number of ways in which conferences can be amplified through use of networked technologies:
*Amplification of the audiences' voice: Prior to the availability of real time chat technologies at events (whether use of IRC, [[Twitter]], instant messaging clients, etc.) it was only feasible to discuss talks with immediate neighbours, and even then this may be considered rude. * Amplification of the speaker's talk: The availability of video and audio-conferencing technologies make it possible for a speaker to be heard by an audience which isn't physically present at the conference. Although use of video technologies has been available to support conferences for some time, this has normally been expensive and require use of dedicated video-conferencing technologies. However the availability of lightweight desktop tools make it much easier to deploy such technologies, without even, requiring the involvement of conference organisers. * Amplification across time: Video and audio technologies can also be used to allow a speaker's talk to be made available after the event, with use of podcasting or videocasting technologies allowing the talks to be easily syndicated to mobile devices as well as accessed on desktop computers. * Amplification of the speaker's slides: The popularity of global repository services for slides, such as [[SlideShare]], enable the slides used by a speaker to be more easily found, embedded on other Web sites and commented upon, in ways that were not possible when the slides, if made available at all, were only available on a conference Web site. * Amplification of feedback to the speaker: Micro-blogging technologies, such as Twitter, are being used not only as a discussion channel for conference participants but also as a way of providing real-time feedback to a speaker during a talk. We are also now seeing dedicated microblogging technologies, such as [[Coveritlive]] and [[ScribbleLive|Scribblelive]], being developed which aim to provide more sophisticated 'back channels' for use at conferences. * Amplification of a conference's collective memory: The popularity of digital cameras and the photographic capabilities of many mobile phones is leading to many photographs being taken at conferences. With such photographs often being uploaded to popular photographic sharing services, such as Flickr, and such collections being made more easy to discover through agreed use of tags, we are seeing amplification of the memories of an event though the sharing of such resources. The ability of such photographic resources to be 'mashed up' with, say, accompanying music, can similarly help to enrich such collective experiences. * Amplification of the learning: The ability to be able to follow links to resources and discuss the points made by a speaker during a talk can enrich the learning which takes place at an event, as described by Shabajee's article on "'Hot' or Not? Welcome to real-time peer review" published in the Times Higher Educational Supplement in May 2003.<ref>{{cite news|author =Shabajee, Paul |title='Hot' or Not? Welcome to real-time peer review|url=http://www.ilrt.bris.ac.uk/~edxps/publications/hot_or_not.html |date=August 1, 2003|accessdate=2008-08-30}}</ref> * Long term amplification of conference outputs: The availability in a digital format of conference resources, including 'official' resources such as slides, video and audio recordings, etc. which have been made by the conference organisers with the approval of speakers, together with more nebulous resources such as archives of conference back channels, and photographs and unofficial recordings taken at the event may help to provide a more authentic record of an event, which could potentially provide a valuable historical record.
The amplification of conferences can be viewed as an example of how new technologies are altering standard practice. By using these techniques a different type of interaction is created at the conference itself, but also the boundaries around the conference can be seen as permeable, with remote participants engaging in discussion. An amplified conference also provides a considerably altered archive compared with a 'traditional' one. For the latter, the printed proceedings will be the main record, but for an amplified event this record is distributed across many media and takes in a wider range of content types, including the papers, videos of the presentations (for example on YouTube), the slides (e.g. on Slideshare), photos of the event (Flickr), interaction between participants (Twitter), reflections and comments (blogs), etc. The amplified conference represents an example of changing practice in digital scholarship.
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Social media]] [[Category:Conferences]]

{{other people||Anne Thompson (disambiguation){{!}}Anne Thompson}} {{Infobox judge | honorific-prefix = | name = Anne Elise Thompson | honorific-suffix = | image = | alt = | caption = | office = [[Senior status|Senior Judge]] of the [[United States District Court for the District of New Jersey]] | term_start = June 1, 2001 | term_end = | office1 = Chief Judge of the [[United States District Court for the District of New Jersey]] | term_start1 = 1994 | term_end1 = 2001 | predecessor1 = [[John F. Gerry]] | successor1 = [[John Winslow Bissell]] | office2 = Judge of the [[United States District Court for the District of New Jersey]] | term_start2 = November 2, 1979 | term_end2 = June 1, 2001 | nominator2 = | appointer2 = [[List of federal judges appointed by Jimmy Carter|Jimmy Carter]] | predecessor2 = ''Seat established by 92 Stat. 1629'' | successor2 = [[Stanley R. Chesler]] | pronunciation = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1934}} | birth_place = [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | citizenship = | nationality = | party = | otherparty = | height = | spouse = | partner = | relations = | children = | parents = | mother = | father = | relatives = | residence = | education = [[Howard University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]])
[[Temple University]] ([[Master of Arts|M.A.]])
[[Howard University School of Law]] ([[Bachelor of Laws|LL.B.]]) | alma_mater = | occupation = | profession = | known_for = | salary = | net_worth = | cabinet = | committees = | portfolio = | religion = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Anne Elise Thompson''' (born 1934) is a [[Senior Status|Senior]] [[United States federal judge|United States District Judge]] of the [[United States District Court for the District of New Jersey]]. ==Education and career== Born in [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]], Thompson received a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree from [[Howard University]] in 1955, a [[Master of Arts]] from [[Temple University]] in 1957, and a [[Bachelor of Laws]] from [[Howard University School of Law]] in 1964. She was an attorney in the Office of the Solicitor of the [[United States Department of Labor]] in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] from 1964 to 1965. She was a grant writer for United Progress, Inc. from 1966 to 1967. She became an assistant deputy public defender for the [[New Jersey Office of the Public Defender]] in the Mercer-Somerset-Hunterdon Region of [[Trenton, New Jersey|Trenton]], [[New Jersey]] from 1967 to 1970. She was the Municipal Prosecutor for [[Lawrence Township, Mercer County, New Jersey|Lawrence Township]] in [[Lawrenceville, New Jersey|Lawrenceville]], New Jersey from 1970 to 1972. She was a municipal court judge for the City of Trenton, New Jersey from 1972 to 1975. She was a prosecutor for [[Mercer County, New Jersey|Mercer County]], New Jersey from 1975 to 1979.{{FJC Bio|2372|nid=1388736|name=Anne Elise Thompson}} ==Federal judicial service== On September 28, 1979, Thompson was nominated by President [[Jimmy Carter]] to a new seat on the [[United States District Court for the District of New Jersey]] created by 92 Stat. 1629. She was confirmed by the [[United States Senate]] on October 31, 1979, and received her commission on November 2, 1979. She served as Chief Judge from 1994 to 2001, and assumed [[senior status]] on June 1, 2001. ==References== {{Reflist}} == Sources == * {{FJC Bio|2372|nid=1388736|name=Anne Elise Thompson}} {{s-start}} {{s-legal}} {{s-bef|before=Seat established by 92 Stat. 1629}} {{s-ttl|title={{nowrap|Judge of the [[United States District Court for the District of New Jersey]]}}|years=1979–2001}} {{s-aft|after=[[Stanley R. Chesler]]}} {{s-bef|before=[[John F. Gerry]]}} {{s-ttl|title={{nowrap|Chief Judge of the [[United States District Court for the District of New Jersey]]}}|years=1994–2001}} {{s-aft|after=[[John Winslow Bissell]]}} {{s-end}} {{United States 3rd Circuit senior district judges}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Thompson, Anne Elise}} [[Category:1934 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American women judges]] [[Category:African-American judges]] [[Category:American judges]] [[Category:Judges of the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey]] [[Category:United States district court judges appointed by Jimmy Carter]] [[Category:20th-century American judges]] [[Category:Howard University alumni]] [[Category:Howard University School of Law alumni]] [[Category:Temple University alumni]] [[Category:Lawyers from Philadelphia]] [[Category:Public defenders]]

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Women's organisations in Spain to [[:Category:Women's organisations based in Spain]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2017 June 25]].
revision.text:
The '''Asociación Nacional de Mujeres Españolas''' (ANME), was a women's rights organisation active in [[Spain]] from 1918 to 1936.
It was not the first women's rights movement in Spain, but was to last longer than any of its predecessors. It was founded in [[Madrid]] in 1918 by [[Consuelo Gonzalez Ramos]] and [[Maria Espinosa de los Monteros]]. Its purpose was to work for women's rights, particularly [[women suffrage]]. It had no support from the Catholic church or any political party, and relied on contributes from sympathizers, and had its meetings on the home of its presidents. In 1919, the ANME founded the [[umbrella organisation]] [[Consejo Feminista de España]] together with the other smaller women's organisations: the [[Sociedad Progresiva Femenina]] and [[La Mujer del Porvenir]] in [[Barcelona]], and the [[Sociedad Concepción Arenal]] and [[Liga para el Progreso de la Mujer]] in [[Valencia]].
From 1921, it published its own paper, the ''Mundo Femenino''.
In 1934, the organisation founded a political feminist party, the [[Acción Política Feminista Independiente]], who tried unsuccessfully to join the leftist coalition. Both the party and the organisation was dissolved under the Spanish civil war.
==See also== * [[Asociación para la Enseñanza de la Mujer]]
==References== * Johnson, Roberta (2003). Gender and Nation in the Spanish Modernist Novel. Vanderbilt University Press. {{ISBN|9780826514370}}.
{{Suffrage}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Asociacion Nacional de Mujeres Espanolas}} [[Category:Feminist organisations in Europe]] [[Category:Women's rights organizations]] [[Category:1918 establishments in Spain]] [[Category:1936 disestablishments in Spain]] [[Category:Feminism and history]] [[Category:Feminism in Spain]] [[Category:Political organisations in Spain]] [[Category:Women's organisations based in Spain]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=June 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Primary sources|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox organization | name = Australian Computer Society | type = Professional Organization | founded_date = 1966 | mission = To promote and develop the ICT profession | key_people = Yohan Ramasundara (President) Andrew Johnson (chief executive officer) | area_served = Australia | focus = Computer and information processing science and technology | method = Publications, Conferences, Technical councils, Industry standards, Certification and training, Scholarships | membership = 26,000+ | homepage ={{url|acs.org.au}} }}
The '''Australian Computer Society''' ('''ACS''') is an association for [[Information technology|information and communications technology]] professionals with over 26,000 members Australia-wide. According to its Constitution, its objects are "to advance professional excellence in information technology" and "to promote the development of Australian information and communications technology resources".<ref>[https://www.acs.org.au/ Australian Computer Society – Home]. www.acs.org.au. Retrieved 15 March 2018.</ref>
The ACS was formed on 1 January 1966 from five state based societies. It was formally incorporated in the [[Australian Capital Territory]] on 3 October 1967. Since 1983 there have been chapters in every state and territory.
The ACS is a member of the Australian Council of Professions ("Professions Australia"), the peak body for professional associations in Australia.<ref>[http://www.professions.com.au/about-us/members/item/australian-computer-society Member: Australian Computer Society]. www.professions.com.au. Retrieved 18 July 2016.</ref> Internationally, ACS is a member of the International Professional Practice Partnership (IP3), [[South East Asia Regional Computer Confederation]], [[International Federation for Information Processing]] and The [[Seoul Accord]].<ref name=About/>
The ACS is also a member organisation of the [[Federation of Enterprise Architecture Professional Organizations]] (FEAPO), a worldwide association of professional organisations which have come together to provide a forum to standardise, professionalise, and otherwise advance the discipline of [[Enterprise Architecture]].
== Activities ==
The ACS operates various chapters, annual conferences, [[Special Interest Group]]s, and a professional development program. Members are required to comply with a Code of Ethics and a Code of Professional Conduct.
== Extent of representation == The ACS describes itself as "the professional association for Australia's Information and Communication Technology (ICT) sector"<ref name=About>{{cite web|title=About Us |url=https://www.acs.org.au/about-the-acs/about-us |website=Australian Computer Society |accessdate=3 August 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RXxnQAS6?url=https://www.acs.org.au/about-the-acs/about-us |archivedate=3 August 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> and "Australia's primary representative body for the ICT workforce",<ref>{{cite journal|title=The art of conversation|journal=Information Age|date=July–August 2013|page=24|url=https://acs.org.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0007/21004/ALL_IA_JulyAugust_2013.pdf|accessdate=4 August 2014|format=PDF|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812211714/https://acs.org.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0007/21004/ALL_IA_JulyAugust_2013.pdf|archive-date=12 August 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> but industry analysts have questioned this based on the small percentage of IT professionals who are ACS members. The issue has been discussed in the press since at least 2004,<ref>{{cite news |last1=Hayes |first1=Simon |title=US body sets up here to rival ACS |url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&AuthType=cookie,ip,cpid,uid&custid=s5945238&db=anh&AN=200412071029002901&site=ehost-live |format=login required |accessdate=1 August 2014 |work=[[The Australian]]|date=7 December 2004|quote=Although the ACS claims about 15,000 members in Australia, about 240,000 people work in the industry.}}</ref> and in 2013 the [[Sydney Morning Herald]] wrote that "the ACS aggressively seeks to control the important software engineering profession in Australia, but ... less than 5 per cent of the professional IT workforce belongs to the ACS."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Healy|first1=Tony|title=IT profession deserves better than the ACS|url=http://www.smh.com.au/it-pro/business-it/it-profession-deserves-better-than-the-acs-20130205-2dw2y.html |accessdate=23 April 2013|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=5 February 2013|at=IT Pro}}</ref> The ACS Foundation came up with a slightly higher figure: "Depending on the data used to calculate the number of ICT professionals in Australia, however, [ACS] membership represents approximately 6.5 per cent of the total."<ref>{{cite book|last=Ridge |first=John (ACS Foundation) |editor1-last=Weckert|editor1-first=John|editor2-last=Lucas|editor2-first=Richard |title=Professionalism in the information and communication technology industry |date=2013 |publisher=Australian National University E Press, co-published with [[Centre for Applied Philosophy and Public Ethics|CAPPE]] |location=Canberra, ACT |isbn=9781922144430|pages=45–48 |url=http://press.anu.edu.au/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/ch025.pdf|accessdate=3 August 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RXyxNaGp?url=http://press.anu.edu.au/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/ch025.pdf|archivedate=3 August 2014|format=PDF|chapter=Chapter 2. The maturing of a profession}}</ref>
== Presidents ==
The Australian Computer Society elects its National President every two years, who serves as the leader of the Society. Some of the most recent presidents include: * [https://ia.acs.org.au/article/2017/acs-elects-new-president.html Yohan Ramasundarah], 2018 – current * [http://www.computerworld.com.au/article/589587/anthony-wong-elected-acs-president/ Anthony Wong], 2016 – 2017 * [https://more.acs.org.au/news-and-media/news/2013/media-alert-brenda-aynsley-elected-acs-president-2014-2016 Brenda Aynsley], 2014 – 2016 * [http://www.arnnet.com.au/article/408515/rdsi_director_dr_nick_tate_elected_new_acs_president/ Nick Tate], 2012 – 2014 * [https://sciencewa.net.au/topics/technology-a-innovation/item/600-ict-centres-of-excellence-open-in-wa Kumar Parakala], 2008 – 2010 * [http://www.itnews.com.au/news/acs-elects-new-president-25998 Philip Argy], 2006 – 2008 * [http://www.computerworld.com.au/article/76608/acs_elects_new_president/ Edward Mandla], 2004 – 2006
== Young IT == The Young IT Professionals Board of the Australian Computer Society provides a voice for young IT professionals and students, as well as a range of services and benefits for members. Currently Young IT organises and runs a bi-annual YIT International Conference and other events such as local career days, soft skills and technical seminars, networking opportunities and social events (e.g. Young IT in the Pub) in each of the Australian States.
The most recent Young IT Conference was held in Melbourne in 2014.
== Publications == "Information Age" is the official publication of the ACS. In February 2015 Information Age became an online only publication. Peer reviewed research publications of the ACS include: * ''Journal of Research and Practice in Information Technology'' * ''Conferences in Research and Practice in Information Technology'' * ''Australasian Journal of Information Systems'' The Digital Library contains free journal articles and conference papers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dl.acs.org.au/|title=ACS Digital Library|accessdate=11 August 2014|registration=yes}}</ref>
== Related organisations == {{div col |colwidth=30em}} * [[Association for Computing Machinery]] * ACS Foundation * [[British Computer Society]] * [[Institution of Analysts and Programmers]] * [[International Federation for Information Processing]] * [[New Zealand Computer Society]] * [[Computer Society of India]] * [[Computer Society of Southern Africa]] * [[Canadian Information Processing Society]] * [[SEARCC]] * [[Seoul Accord]] {{div col end}}
===Other Australian computer associations=== * [[AUUG]] – Now deregistered * [[Linux Australia]] * [[LUGs in Australia]] * [[SAGE-AU]] * [[Institute of Analytics Professionals of Australia]] (IAPA), incorporating business data analytics, business intelligence, data mining and related industries * [[Australian Software Innovation Forum]], encourages collaboration and co-operation in Java EE and associated technologies
== Special Interest Groups ==
Special Interest Groups (SIGs) of the ACS are connected to each state branch with some SIGs of the same or similar name occurring in a number of states, depending on local interest, and include: Architects, Software Quality Assurance, Women in Technology, Business Requirements Analysis, Enterprise Capacity Management, Enterprise Solution Development, Free Open Source Software, Information Security, IT Management, Project Management, Service Oriented Computing, Web Services, Consultants and Contractors, IT Security, PC Recycling, Curry SIG, Information Technology in Education, Robotics, E-Commerce, IT Governance, Software Engineering and Cloud Computing. A recent addition is the Green ICT Group on computers and telecommunications for environmental sustainability. In 2007 the [[Telecommunications Society of Australia]] was absorbed into the Australian Computer Society as the Telecommunications Special Interest Group
== Education and Certification ==
The ACS runs the online Computer Professional Education Program (CPEP) for postgraduate education in subjects including: Green ICT Strategies; New Technology Alignment; Business, Strategy & IT; Adaptive Business Intelligence; Project Management; Managing Technology and Operations. CPEP uses the Australian developed [[Moodle]] course management system and is delivered via the web.
The Diploma of Information Technology (DIT) is equivalent to one academic year of a Bachelor of Information Technology at several universities. It has eight compulsory subjects: systems analysis, programming, computer organisation, data management, OO systems development, computer communications, professional practice and systems principles.
The ACS also certifies IT professionals at two levels, the Certified Professional and the Certified Technologist. Each certification level has a minimum level of experience and also required ongoing CPD (Certified Professional Development) hours of learning each year. In 2017 the ACS launched a cybersecurity specialisation within the certification framework.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/cybersecurity-specialisation-status-up-for-grabs-with-new-acs-accreditation-program/|title=Cybersecurity specialisation status up for grabs with new ACS accreditation program {{!}} ZDNet|last=McLean|first=Asha|publisher=ZDNet|access-date=29 September 2017}}</ref>

{{hatnote|See also: [[Confession (law)|Confessions in law]], [[Confession (religion)|Confessions in religion]], and [[Confession (disambiguation)]] and [[Confessions (disambiguation)]].}} {{redirect|Confess}} [[File:The Progress of Love - Love Letters - Fragonard 1771-72.jpg|thumb|''Confession of Love'' by [[Jean-Honoré Fragonard]] depicts a subject confessing feelings that had been concealed up to that point.]]
A '''confession''' is a statement – made by a person or by a group of persons – acknowledging some personal fact that the person (or the group) would ostensibly prefer to keep hidden. The term presumes that the speaker is providing information that he believes the other party is not already aware of,<ref name="Shuy">Roger W. Shuy, ''The Language of Confession, Interrogation, and Deception'' (1998), p. 2–10.</ref> and is frequently associated with an admission of a moral or legal wrong: {{quote|In one sense it is the acknowledgment of having done something wrong, whether on purpose or not. Thus confessional texts usually provide information of a private nature previously unavailable. What a sinner tells a priest in the confessional, the documents criminals sign acknowledging what they have done, an autobiography in which the author acknowledges mistakes, and so on, are all examples of confessional texts.<ref>Jorge J. E. Gracia, ''A Theory of Textuality: The Logic and Epistemology'' (1995), p. 94–95.</ref>}}
Not all confessions reveal wrongdoing, however. For example, a confession of [[love]] is often considered positive both by the confessor and by the recipient of the confession, and is a common theme in literature.<ref>Giulio Marra, ''Shakespeare and this "imperfect" World: Dramatic Form and the Nature of Knowing'' (1997), p. 69, describing "the distinction between "to do" and "to confess", between having thoughts of love and confessing one's love, between the indetermination of a feeling and its final definition", as a theme that "creeps into the various stories".</ref><ref>Charles Emil Kany, ''The Beginnings of the Epistolary Novel in France, Italy and Spain'' (1937), Volume 21, Issues 1-6, p. 19.</ref> With respect to confessions of wrongdoing, there are several specific kinds of confessions that have significance beyond the social. A [[Confession (law)|legal confession]] involves an admission of some wrongdoing that has legal consequence, while the concept of [[Confession (religion)|confession in religion]] varies widely across various belief systems, and is usually more akin to a [[ritual]] by which the person acknowledges thoughts or actions considered [[sin]]ful or morally wrong within the confines of the confessor's religion. In some religions, confession takes the form of an [[oral communication]] to another person. Socially, however, the term may refer to admissions that are neither legally nor religiously significant.<ref name="Shuy"/>
== Psychology == Confession often benefits the one who is confessing . [[Paul Wilkes]] characterizes confession as "a pillar of mental health" because of its ability to relieve [[anxiety|anxieties]] associated with keeping [[Secrecy|secrets]].<ref> {{cite book | last1 = Wilkes | first1 = Paul | author-link1 = Paul Wilkes | title = The Art of Confession: Renewing Yourself Through the Practice of Honesty | url = | publisher = Workman Publishing | publication-date = 2012 | page = xi | isbn = 9780761168720 | quote = Confession is also a pillar of mental health, for confession is about self-examination. It demands something for which there is no substitute: that we be honest with ourselves. }}<!--| accessdate = 2015-07-27--> </ref> Confessants are more likely to confess when the expected benefits outweigh the marginal costs (when the benefit of the offense to them is high, the cost to the victim is low, and the probability of information leakage is high).<ref> {{cite journal|last1= Sznycer|first1= Daniel|last2= Schniter|first2= Eric|last3= Tooby|first3= John|last4= Cosmides|first4= Leda|title= Regulatory adaptations for delivering information: The case of confession|journal= Evolution and Human Behavior|date= 5 September 2014|doi= 10.1016/j.evolhumbehav.2014.08.008|pmc= 4313746}} </ref> People may undertake social confessions in order to relieve feelings of guilt or to seek forgiveness from a wronged party, but such confessions may also serve to create social bonds between the confessant and the confessor, and may prompt the listener to reply with confessions of their own.<ref name="Shuy"/> A person may therefore confess wrongdoing to another person as a means of creating such a social bond, or of extracting [[Reciprocity (social psychology)|reciprocal]] information from the other person.<ref name="Shuy"/> A confession may be made in a self-aggrandizing manner, as a way for the confessant to claim credit for a misdeed for the purpose of eliciting a reaction to that claim.<ref name="Shuy"/>
==Law== {{main|Confession (law)|Statement against interest}} In law, there is [[declaration against interest|an exception]] to the [[hearsay]] rule that allows testimony concerning someone else's confession to be admitted if the statement had a great enough tendency "to expose the declarant to civil or criminal liability". The theory is that a reasonable person would not make such a [[false confession]].<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.law.cornell.edu/rules/fre/rule_804|title= Rule 804. Hearsay Exceptions; Declarant Unavailable|author= |date= |work= LII / Legal Information Institute|access-date= 28 April 2016}}</ref> In U.S. law, a confession must be [[voluntariness|voluntary]] in order to be admissible.<ref> {{cite web |url= https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/18/3501 |title= 18 U.S. Code § 3501 - Admissibility of confessions |author= |date= |work= LII / Legal Information Institute |access-date=28 April 2016 }} </ref>
Confessions (whether [[forced confession | forced]] or otherwise) may feature in formal or informal [[show trial]]s.<ref> Note for example: {{cite book | last1 = Cook | first1 = Alexander C. | chapter = Testimony | title = The Cultural Revolution on Trial: Mao and the Gang of Four | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=o4YHDgAAQBAJ | publisher = Cambridge University Press | publication-date = 2016 | page = 118 | isbn = 9781316785096 | access-date = 2017-09-08 | quote = [...] there is no evidence, either in the available documents or in [[Wang Hongwen]]'s shallow personality, to suggest he arrived at his confession through a searching self-examination in the manner of [[Nikolai Bukharin]]'s elaborately conceived philosophical confession presented in his Stalin-era show trial. }} </ref>
== Socialisation== Public confessions play a role in [[struggle session]]s<ref> {{cite book | last1 = Williams | first1 = Philip F. | author-link1 = | last2 = Wu | first2 = Yenna | chapter = The PRC Prison Camp (II): From Struggle Sessions to Release or Death | title = The Great Wall of Confinement: The Chinese Prison Camp Through Contemporary Fiction and Reportage | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ybEwDwAAQBAJ | location = Berkeley | publisher = University of California Press | publication-date = 2004 | page = 115 | isbn = 9780520244023 | access-date = 2017-09-08 | quote = During a 'study' session, the person receiving criticism usually makes a substantial verbal response of some sort. [...] In contrast, objects of a struggle session are typically expected to bow their heads contritely, bend forward at the waist, and succinctly confess their guilt ''[ren zui]''. [...] The required parts of the struggle session ritual include the stage or platform where the bowed objects of the strugle stand contritely next to gesticulating and slogan-shouting cadres or other leaders, along with the audience seated nearby, who parrot the slogans in a shouted refrain. For example, Song Shan remarks that all seventy-six times she was subjected to a struggle session in front of thousands of people, the format of the event was exactly the same. }} </ref> and in other methods of [[social control]] and influence involving [[self-criticism]].<ref> {{cite book | last1 = Mead | first1 = George Herbert | author-link1 = George Herbert Mead | chapter = The Social Foundations and Functions of Thought and Communication | orig-year = 1934 | editor1-last = Morris | editor1-first = Charles W. | editor1-link = Charles W. Morris | title = Mind, Self, and Society: The Definitive Edition | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=22jtBwAAQBAJ | location = Chicago | publisher = University of Chicago Press | publication-date = 2015 | page = 255 | isbn = 9780226112879 | access-date = 2017-09-08 | quote = [...] through self-criticism, social control over individual behavior or conduct operates by virtue of the social origin and basis of such criticism. That is to say, self-criticism is essentially social criticism, and behavior controlled by self-criticism is essentiall behavior controlled socially. }} </ref><ref> {{cite book | last1 = Pennebaker | first1 = James W. | author-link1 = | chapter = 12: Confession in Context: Therapy Religion and Brainwashing | title = Opening Up: The Healing Power of Expressing Emotions | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=U2doiTNg134C | location = New York | publisher = The Guilford Press | publication-date = 2012 | page = 172 | isbn = 9781462504848 | access-date = 2017-09-08 | quote = Confession also occurs outside religious institutions. Within political systems that actively discourage religion, such as offshoots of Marxism, forms of confession or self-criticism are fostered. }} </ref>
==See also== * [[Atonement in Judaism]] * [[Repentance]]
==References== {{reflist}}

'''Crime in Serbia''' is combated by the [[Police of the Republic of Serbia|Serbian Police]] and other government agencies.
== Crime by type ==
=== Murder === {{Further information|List of countries by intentional homicide rate}}
In 2012, Serbia had a murder rate of 1.2 per 100,000 population.<ref name=UNODC/> There were a total of 111 murders in Serbia in 2012.<ref name=UNODC>[https://www.unodc.org/gsh/en/index.html ''Global Study on Homicide''. [[United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime]], 2013.]</ref>
=== Organised crime === {{Main article|Serbian mafia}} '''Serbian Organised Crime''' ({{lang-sr|Cpпска мафија}} / ''Srpska Mafija'', ''Serbian Mafia'') are various criminal organisations based in [[Serbia]] or composed of ethnic [[Serbs]]. Serbian criminals are active in the [[European Union]] (EU) countries. The organisations are primarily involved in [[smuggling]], [[arms trafficking]], [[drug trafficking]], [[protection racket]], [[illegal gambling]], jewelry and gems theft, [[bodyguarding]], and [[contract killing]]. The Mafia is composed of several major organised groups, which in turn have wider networks throughout primarily Europe.
The [[Yugoslav Wars]] prompted criminals a "way out" of economic disaster during the international imposed sanctions against Serbia. Serbian criminals have been recruited to state security forces, a notable example is [[Legija]], a commander in the [[Arkan's Tigers]] which after the war was re-labeled as the [[JSO (Special Operations Unit)|JSO]] (''Red Berets''), he planned the murder of Prime Minister [[Zoran Đinđić]].<ref name=GRAZ>[http://www.etc-graz.at/cms/fileadmin/user_upload/humsec/Journal/Stojarova_Organized_Crime_in_the_Western_Balkans.pdf ''Organized Crime in the Western Balkans'']</ref>
=== Corruption === {{Further information|Corruption in Serbia}}
Corruption levels are perceived to be high by surveyed residents of Serbia, and public trust in key institutions remains low.<ref name="Global Integrity">{{cite web|title=The Global Integrity Report 2011- Serbia|url=http://www.globalintegrity.org/report/Serbia/2011|publisher=Global Integrity|accessdate=22 April 2014}}</ref>
Public procurement, public administration recruitment processes, mining and rail operations are sectors with a serious problem of conflict of interest.<ref name="Global Integrity"/> The European Commission has raised concern over Serbia's judiciary, police, health and education sectors that are particularly vulnerable to corruption.<ref>{{cite web|title=SERBIA 2013 PROGRESS REPORT|url=http://ec.europa.eu/enlargement/pdf/key_documents/2013/package/sr_rapport_2013.pdf|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=22 April 2014}}</ref> [[Transparency Serbia]] estimated in September 2016 that at least 374,000 cases of "petty corruption" in public services remain undiscovered every year.<ref name="Transparency International's GCB">{{cite web|url= http://www.transparentnost.org.rs/index.php/en/110-english/naslovna/8711-unreported-corruption-is-the-biggest-problem-measures-of-the-state-so-far-without-success |title=Unreported corruption is the biggest problem, measures of the state so far without success, |author=Transparency Serbia's Press Issue on GCB 2015|website=Transparentnost.org.rs|accessdate=2016-11-01}}</ref>
=== Piracy === Piracy in Serbia is increasing in intensity in [[2000s (decade)|2000s]] and 2010s<!-- U poslednjih desetak godina -->.<ref>{{cite news |last=Ilić |first=J. |date=2014-09-26 |title= Smederevo: Pirati haraju na Dunavu |url=http://www.novosti.rs/vesti/srbija.73.html:511844-Smederevo-Pirati-haraju-na-Dunavu |newspaper=Večernje novosti |location=Belgrade |accessdate=2014-12-24 }}</ref> Especially threatened is the shipping on the part of [[Danube]] between [[Belgrade]] and [[Smederevo]].<ref name=rpbtnp>{{cite news |last=Vukasović |first=Vladimir |date=2008-12-04 |title=Речни "пирати" бољи трговци него пљачкаши |url=http://www.politika.rs/sr/clanak/65725/Drustvo/Recni-pirati-bolji-trgovci-nego-pljackasi |newspaper=Politika |location=Belgrade |accessdate=2015-12-22 }}</ref> Most commonly, pirates will plunder [[bulk cargo]] such as oil, [[Coke (fuel)|coke]], metals, grains, sugar or fertilizers, but sometimes also remove cables and electric motors from the ships.<ref name="rpbtnp" />
The confrontations of the pirates with the crews rarely escalate, with a single shipman murder recorded, in late-2000s<!-- -->.<ref name=rpbtnp/> This is, in part, because crews will often cooperate with the pirates, sell part of the cargo, then report the piracy in order to receive insurance money.<ref name=snddidns>{{cite news |last1=Vukasović |first1=Vladimir |last2=Luković |first2=Marko |date=2010-05-27 |title=Шверц нафте дуж Дунава и даље "национални спорт" |url=http://www.politika.rs/rubrike/Beograd/SHverc-nafte-duz-Dunava-i-dalje-nacionalni-sport.html |newspaper=Politika |location=Belgrade |accessdate=2015-02-12 }}</ref><ref name=ssib>{{cite news |last=Ilić |first=J. |date=2012-03-16 |title=Smederevo: Šverc istočio barže |url=http://www.novosti.rs/vesti/naslovna/aktuelno.291.html:371047-Smederevo-Sverc-istocio-barze |newspaper=Večernje novosti |location=Belgrade |accessdate=2015-01-19 }}</ref> Cases of cooperation of the pirates with the police have also been recorded.<ref name=ssib/>
The pirates will also often engage in smuggling fuel and other goods across Danube.<ref name=snddidns/>
=== False bomb threats === False [[bomb threat]]s are relatively common in Serbia. Since the police reacts to every bomb threat by searching the entire buildings for the possible bomb,<ref name=lbuoim>{{cite news |last=Vasiljević |first=B |date=2008-02-29 |title=Лажне "бомбашке" узбуне – опасне игре малолетника |url=http://www.politika.rs/rubrike/Beograd/Lazne-bombashke-uzbune-opasne-igre-maloletnika.html |newspaper=Politika |location=Belgrade |accessdate=2014-12-24 }}</ref> most common targets are schools<ref name=lbuoim/> where students will phone in a threat to delay their exams, and courts<ref name=pldobpp>{{cite news |author=Tanjug |date=2014-09-26 |title=Поново лажна дојава о бомби у Палати правде |url=http://www.politika.rs/vesti/najnovije-vesti/Ponovo-lazna-dojava-o-bombi-u-Palati-pravde.html |newspaper=Politika |location=Belgrade |accessdate=2014-12-24 }}</ref> where people expecting to lose a trial will phone in to delay it. Due to false bomb threats, the building of the High Court in [[Belgrade]]<!-- Palata pravde --> had to be evacuated more than 70 times in 2008<ref name=pldobpp/>
Less common targets include those as diverse as Belgrade firefighters' headquarters,<ref>{{cite news |author=T.M:S. |date=2014-12-11 |title=Lažna dojava o bombi u sedištu Vatrogasne brigade u Beogradu |url=http://www.blic.rs/Vesti/Hronika/518558/Lazna-dojava-o-bombi-u-sedistu-Vatrogasne-brigade-u-Beogradu |newspaper=Blic |location=Belgrade |accessdate=2014-12-24 }}</ref> a residential building<ref name=zpbt>{{cite news |last=Vasiljević |first=B. |date=2011-05-24 |title=Закон прекида бомбашку "телефонијаду" |url=http://www.politika.rs/rubrike/Beograd/Zakon-prekida-bombasku-telefonijadu.html |newspaper=Politika |location=Belgrade |accessdate=2014-12-24 }}</ref> or [[Kraljevo]] public library.<ref>{{cite news |author=Tanjug |date=2011-11-08 |title=Kraljevo: Lažna dojava o bombi u Narodnoj biblioteci |url=http://www.novosti.rs/vesti/srbija.73.html:352531-Kraljevo-Lazna-dojava-o-bombi-u-Narodnoj-biblioteci |newspaper=Večernje novosti |location=Belgrade |accessdate=2014-12-24 }}</ref>
Frequency of the false bomb threats was reduced in 2009, after a new law specified harsher, triplified, punishments.<ref name=zpbt/>
==Crime dynamics== Serbian law enforcement authorities have prioritised fighting drug trafficking, terrorism and organised crime during the late 2000s.<ref>http://www.emg.rs/en/news/serbia/156009.html</ref>
